title: typeface design book suggestions?
content:
Could anyone suggest any titles of books that deal with typeface design, particularly the basics of letterform construction - ie with pen, ruler & compass? Ideally with visual examples of how the different forms are constructed…  
I’ve been trying to construct some ‘traditional’ faces for a poster, but am struggling with some of the letterforms (particularly s, g and e…) I had a look through my college library and considering the size and reputation of it it doesn’t seem to have any such books!  
Many thanks.
author: mbusher

comments.content:
mbusher … look under the subject of ‘lettering’ and you might have better luck.

[HERE IS A SCAN](http://web.archive.org/web/20051111100839/http:/www.agency26.com/letters1.jpg) from _Lettering Art in Modern Use_ by Raymond A. Ballinger. (1952)

You can see the mechanical pencil outlines on the tissue paper. Underneath, is  
the revision with optical corrections.

Doyald Young’s [two books](http://web.archive.org/web/20051111100839/http:/www.delphipress.com/) (Logotypes & Letterforms, Fonts & Logos) are pretty strongly oriented towards lettering-based font construction, and Leslie Cabarga’s Logo, Font & Lettering Bible has a lot of good stuff. As for the rest, yeah, use Google to search Typophile and look for threads on [lettering](http://web.archive.org/wiki/lettering). The Cabarga and Young books have the advantage of being in print, but when it comes to lettering, they only touch the top of the iceberg.

i’ll try that monday when i’m back at college. i was looking in the typography / type design section, which is probably why i couldn’t find anything. according to the catalogue they have a copy of the book you suggested so i’ll pick it up.  
Thanks for the suggestions.

I’ll just add that there is little in type design that \*actually\* uses a compass. Even stuff that looks geometric usually isn’t, and normal lettering is much more organic than constructed.

That isn’t to say that there isn’t consistency - but it’s of a different sort.

Regards,

T

_I’ll just add that there is little in type design that \*actually\* uses a compass. Even stuff that looks geometric usually isn’t, and normal lettering is much more organic than constructed._

Not to mention that no existing font format (that I’m aware of, at least) supports rational curves, so even if the type was designed with a compass, it won’t be perfectly circular.
